Highlights • This study models airport capacity investments with real options. Analytical solutions are obtained and benchmarked across different scenarios. • Airline competition, commercial revenue, demand uncertainty, and an airport's alternative objectives are explicitly considered in a multi-stage game. • An airport can use real options to improve its expected profit or social welfare. The magnitude of this improvement and the optimal size of the expansion real option both increase with demand uncertainty. • A profit-maximizing airport will choose a smaller capacity to invest immediately and a smaller reserve than a welfare-maximizing airport. • Airline competition promotes airport capacity investments and the adoption of real options by profit-maximizing airports, whereas airport commercial services enhance immediate capacity investments but not the size of the reserve. Abstract This study models airport capacity choice when a real option for expansion can be purchased. Facing demand uncertainty, an airport first determines the capacity for immediate investment (the prior capacity) and the size of the land or other resources to be reserved for possible future expansion (the reserve). Once demand is observed, the airport can use a portion of the reserve to build extra capacity and set airport charge. Our analytical results show that if demand uncertainty is low and capacity and reserve costs are relatively high, an airport will not acquire a real option for expansion. Otherwise, it can use an expansion option to improve its expected profit or social welfare. Both the magnitude of profit or welfare gain and the optimal size of the reserve increase with demand uncertainty. A higher reserve cost leads to a larger prior capacity and a smaller reserve, whereas a higher capital cost leads to lower prior capacity. A profit-maximizing airport would choose a smaller prior capacity and reserve than would a welfare-maximizing airport. Competition within the airline market promotes airport capacity investment and the adoption of real options by profit-maximizing airports, whereas airport commercial services increase prior capacity but not the reserve. Keywords Airport capacity choice Capacity investment Real options Demand uncertainty 1 Introduction Airport capacity investment is lumpy and requires a lengthy planning and construction process. Moreover, the investment decision is made facing significant demand uncertainty (De Neufville and Barber, 1991; Maldonaldo, 1990; Oum and Zhang, 1990). As a result, capacity at many airports is either under- or over-invested, 1 1 The Montreal Mirabel Airport, new Denver International Airport, and Kansai International Airport are examples of over-investment that led to capacity under-use, either in the short and/or long term. The Newark airport in New York also experienced extended periods of under-use (De Neufville and Odoni 2003). The Amsterdam Schiphol Airport and Hong Kong International Airport (Chek Lap Kok) are examples of under-investment that led to capacity shortages much earlier than expected. and non-optimal airport capacity leads to huge social welfare losses (De Neufville and Odoni, 2003). In this paper, we show that airports can use real options to improve the efficiency of their capacity investments, and we discuss the economic and policy implications of applying real options to airport capacity investment. This paper is motivated by the business strategies adopted by airports to deal with demand uncertainty in making investment decisions. Under one strategy, nearby land is reserved for possible future expansion, a practice called “land banking.” For example, UPS worked with Louisville airport to secure space for the future expansion of its WorldPort sorting center. In another example, Seoul Inchon airport had only two runways when it opened, but large areas of land were reserved for possible future expansion to a maximum of five runways. Due to an increase in traffic, part of the reserved land has already been converted to capacity. Taipei Taoyuan International Airport also reserved nearby farmland for extended periods before designating it for airport expansion in 2011. Another strategy used by airports incorporates flexible design into operations and planning. Flexible designs allow airports to adjust their capacity under new circumstances. For example, the Hong Kong International Airport adopted a self-propelled intra-airport passenger transport system which cost more than a cable-driven system at low traffic volume but provided long-term flexibility for capacity expansion. These strategies, land banking and flexible design, are applications of “real options” in airport capacity planning (Transportation Research Board (TRB) 2012). 2 2 Applications of real options in airport capacity planning identified in the TRB report include land banking, reservation of terminal space, modular or incremental development, linear terminal design and centralized processing facilities, swing gates or spaces, non-load-bearing or glass walls and self-propelled people movers. By making investments at an early stage, real options provide the right, but not the obligation, to take certain courses of action at later stages when more information becomes available. Driouchi et al. (2012) point out that the main essence of real options is that they confer on their owners the ability to partly reverse commitments and to postpone decision-making until additional information is available. Motivated by these business strategies, we build a model for airport capacity investment and investigate the effect that real options for expansion have on consumer surplus and the profits of airlines and airports. The real option in our paper is modeled as the land or other resources reserved for possible future airport capacity expansion, although the conclusions should hold for other real option applications. The built model has the following key features. First, capacity investment at an airport follows a multi-stage decision process: the airport first determines the initial capacity (prior capacity) and the size of the land or other resources reserved for possible future expansion (the reserve), and then uses a portion of the reserve to add incremental capacity given the realization of random demand. Second, the model incorporates airports’ pricing decisions. Airport charges are made after the total capacity (prior capacity plus incremental capacity) is invested. Third, we consider both welfare-maximizing and profit-maximizing airports, which serve as benchmark cases to model the effect of airport ownership. Finally, airline competition is explicitly modeled, accounting for the vertical relationship between airlines and airports. Airlines engage in Cournot competition given an airport's capacity and charges, and the equilibrium outcomes from airline competition determine the traffic volume of the airport. This paper is related to three broad streams of literature: that on modeling airport capacity investment, that on the effects of demand uncertainty on capacity choice and pricing in transportation sectors, and that on using real options in transport infrastructure investment. Studies modeling airport capacity investment mostly consider deterministic demand. 3 3 Examples of these studies include Zhang and Zhang (2003), Oum et al. (2004), Forsyth (2005, 2007), Basso and Zhang (2007, 2008), Zhang and Zhang (2010), Zhang (2010). A few studies model the effects of demand uncertainty on managing airport congestion (Czerny, 2008, 2010), highway pricing and capacity choice (D’ Ouville and McDonald, 1990; Kraus, 1982) and congestible infrastructure in general (Basso and Zhang, 2007; Proost and Van der Loo, 2010). Contrary to these papers in which capacity and price are determined simultaneously, we explicitly account for large sunk costs and long project cycles in airport capacity investment by extending the analytical model of Xiao et al. (2013). In this model, airport capacity investment and pricing are viewed as sequential decisions. Demand uncertainty matters especially for investment decisions when sunk costs are high and project cycles are long, as they are in airport capacity investment. Lumpy investments and long project cycles make real options valuable tools for airports to use in effectively investing. The application of real options to transportation sectors has been studied under the modeling framework of Dixit and Pindyck (1994). 4 4 Examples of these studies include De Neufville (2003, 2008), Law et al. (2004), Chambers (2007), Martins (2013), Martins et al. (2014), Morgado et al. (2013), Gao and Driouchi (2013), Galera and Soliño (2010), Chow and Regan (2011a,2011b) and Smit (2003). For discussions of real options analysis and decision making in general, see Trigeorgis (1993, 1996), Driouchi and Bennett (2012), Driouchi et al. (2010), Chevalier-Roignant et al. (2011), and Trigeorgis and Reuer (2017). These studies focus on the valuation and pricing of real options, and the choice of timing given the possibility of deferred investments. The study most related to our paper is Smit's (2003), which analyzes optimal airport investment when an airport's future free cash-flow is uncertain. Heuristic solutions and numerical simulations are used to draw conclusions under very specific market conditions. In comparison, our paper focuses on the effects real options have on the efficiency of airports with different objectives (welfare maximizing vs. profit maximizing), and the policy implications for government regulation when airports use real options in their capacity investments. As such, our model allows us to draw clear insights from analytical results. We find that if demand uncertainty is low and capacity and reserve costs are relatively high, an airport will not acquire a real option for expansion. Otherwise, an airport can use an expansion option to improve its expected profit or social welfare. Both the magnitude of profit or welfare gain and the optimal size of the reserve increase with demand uncertainty. A higher reserve cost leads to a larger prior capacity and a smaller reserve, whereas a higher capital cost leads to lower prior capacity. A profit-maximizing airport would choose a smaller prior capacity and reserve than a welfare-maximizing airport would. Competition within the airline market promotes airport capacity investment and the adoption of real options by profit-maximizing airports, whereas airport commercial services increase prior capacity but not the reserve. In general, our study suggests that real options can be valuable tools for the aviation industry to battle uncertainty. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the economic model and provides analytical solutions for a profit-maximizing airport. The case of a welfare-maximizing airport is studied in Section 3. Section 4 compares and discusses the modeling results of different cases, and possible complicating factors in practical evaluations of business strategies and regulatory policies. The last section concludes the paper and discusses its limitations and possible future extensions. 2 Economic model and the case of a profit-maximizing airport 2.1 Economic model In this section we introduce the economic model of real option application, and use the model to analyze the capacity investment of a profit-maximizing airport. We extend the model in Xiao et al. (2013) to consider a single, risk-neutral airport that invests in capacity to accommodate its future traffic volume. The travel demand of airlines is P = X − b Q (b > 0), where P is the price paid by travelers (i.e., the airfare), Q is the traffic volume, and X is a random variable that captures the demand forecast's margin of error (the demand shifters that cannot be precisely estimated). There are N airlines competing in Cournot. Each airline produces an output (traffic volume) of qi ( i = 1 … N ), such that Q = ∑ i = 1 N q i . The airlines are symmetric in the sense that they all have a constant marginal cost c. Therefore, the effects of airline competition can be analyzed by checking comparative statics with respect to N. Let f(x) be the density function of X and F(x) be the corresponding distribution function. For tractability, X is assumed to follow a uniform distribution in the interval ( x ̲ , x ¯ ) , so f ( x ) = 1 / ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) and ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) measures the degree of demand uncertainty or variability. The airport sets a service charge per passenger, w, and derives concession revenue, h, from each passenger. The associated consumer surplus is v. Both h and v are assumed to be positive and exogenously determined. 5 5 For alternative modeling of concession services, see Czerny (2006, 2013) and Yang and Zhang (2011). Without loss of generality, the marginal cost of the airport is normalized to zero. We model the capacity investment of the airport as a multi-stage game to account for its pricing decisions and vertical relationships with its airlines. In Stage 1, based on the distribution of the demand shifter f(x), the airport determines its prior capacity Kf , which is immediately usable (e.g., the number of runways that are immediately built), and its reserve Kr (e.g., the land it reserves for possible future expansion). The unit cost of capacity is r and the unit cost of the reserve is r*. The airport investment cost at this first stage is thus r K f + r * K r . In stage 2, the airport observes the actual traffic demand pattern X and then uses a certain amount of the reserve (i.e. part of the land Kr purchased during Stage 1) to add an incremental capacity K (K ≤ Kr ) with a unit capacity cost r. Capacity invested in at a later stage can become costlier due to inflation. Such an increase in investment cost is not explicitly modeled due to mathematical tractability. Intuitively, ceteris paribus, a higher capacity cost in the future should increase the immediate investment (i.e., prior capacity) but reduce the future capacity investments, and thus also the reserve purchased. In Stage 3, conditional on the observed demand shifter X (and thus the actual observed demand), and the total available capacity K f + K , the airport sets its airport charge w to maximize its profit or total social welfare. Finally, in Stage 4, airlines engage in Cournot competition to maximize their own profits, and the equilibrium outcomes from airline competition determine the traffic volume at the airport. The multi-stage game is summarized as follows: ○ Stage 1: The airport determines its prior capacity Kf and reserve Kr . ○ Stage 2: The airport observes the actual traffic demand pattern X and uses part of the reserve to add incremental capacity K (K ≤ Kr ). ○ Stage 3: The airport sets its charge w to maximize its profit or total social welfare. ○ Stage 4: The airlines engage in Cournot competition to maximize their respective profits. Under the multi-stage game framework, we compare a capacity investment decision made by a profit-maximizing airport with one made by a welfare-maximizing airport. The comparison is based on the assumption that r* ≤ r/4, which is likely to hold in practice because the capacity cost is usually much greater than the cost of the reserve. For example, the cost of building an airport is usually much higher than the cost of reserving the land needed to build it on. This assumption does not affect the model's solutions but makes the comparison between a profit-maximizing and a welfare-maximizing airport feasible. Moreover, we assume that x ̲ ≥ c + r − h , which ensures that the airport capacity is non-negative for any X ∈ ( x ̲ , x ¯ ) . This game is solved backward to obtain the sub-game perfect Nash equilibrium. In the last-stage of the sequential game, an airline i chooses the output to maximize its profit πi given the available airport capacity K f + K , airport service charge w and observed demand shifter X. The profit maximizing problem is: (1) M a x q i π i | K f , K , w , X = ( X − b Q − c − w ) q i s . t . Q = ∑ i = 1 N q i ≤ K f + K Solving the profit-maximizing problem, we obtain the following results for the airport's derived demand. Some of the relevant results on airport capacity and the use of reserve are summarized in Proposition 1. Proposition 1 A profit-maximizing airport with observed travel demand X, invested prior capacity Kf and reserve Kr will exercise the following amount of its reserve. (a) If X ≤ c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b K f , the airport will not use its reserve. No incremental capacity will be invested in, or K * = 0 . (b) If c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b K f < X < c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b ( K f + K r ) , the airport will use part of its reserve. The extra capacity invested in is (9.1) K * = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( X − c − r + h ) − K f . (c) If X ≥ c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b ( K f + K r ) , the airport will use all of its reserve. The incremental capacity invested in is (9.2) K * = K r . The intuition of Proposition 1 is as follows. When the observed travel demand X is low and the prior capacity Kf is high, such that X ≤ c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b K f , there is no need to use the reserve to add more capacity. If the observed travel demand X is high but the prior capacity Kf and reserve Kr are low, such that X ≥ c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b ( K f + K r ) , all of the reserve will be used and K * = K r . In the intermediate case when c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b K f < X < c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b ( K f + K r ) , part of the reserve will be used to provide an optimal final available capacity. In the final step of the backward induction, the airport chooses its prior capacity Kf and reserve Kr to maximize its expected profit EΠ. The airport's profit-maximizing problem is formally: (10) M a x K f , K r E Π = E [ ( w * + h ) Q * − r ( K f + K * ) − r * K r ] where w*, Q*, and K* are the optimal airport charge, airport derived demand, and optimal incremental capacity invested at Stage 2, respectively. Proposition 2 suggests that a profit-maximizing airport's optimal prior capacity and reserve are influenced by many factors, including the capital cost r, reserve cost r*, and demand uncertainty as measured by x ¯ − x ̲ . If the cost of the reserve is sufficiently low, such that r * ≤ m i n { x ¯ − x ̲ 8 , r 2 2 ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) } , the airport will always invest in some reserve. Otherwise, whether reserve will be acquired depends on the relative size of the capital cost r and the variability x ¯ − x ̲ of future demand. If both the capital cost and reserve cost are relatively high but the demand uncertainty is low, such that r ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ 2 and r * ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ 8 , no reserve will be invested in. 3 Welfare-maximizing airport In this section we model the prior capacity and reserve choices of an airport that aims to maximize expected social welfare. We use the welfare-maximizing case as the benchmark to be compared with the profit-maximizing case. Social welfare SW is the sum of the consumer surplus, and the airlines’ and airport's profits as follows: (15) S W = [ ∫ 0 Q P ( φ , X ) d φ − P Q + v Q ] + [ ∑ i ( P − c − w ) q i ] + [ ( w + h ) Q − r ( K f + K ) − r * K r ] = − b 2 Q 2 + ( X + h + v − c ) − r ( K f + K ) − r * K r where Q is the derived demand of the airport solved in Lemma 1 and v denotes the consumer surplus derived from the consumption of commercial services per passenger. Given the solutions for Stage 4 as summarized in Lemma 1, in Stage 3 the airport sets its service charge w to maximize expected welfare conditional on its available capacity K f + K . We have the following results. Lemma 3 For a welfare-maximizing airport, with derived airport demand Q(Kf, K, w, X), available airport capacity K f + K , and observed travel demand pattern X: (a) if c − h − v < X < c + b ( K f + K ) − h − v , the optimal airport charge is (16.1) w o p t | K f , K , X = − X − c N + ( N + 1 ) ( h + v ) N (b) if X ≥ c + b ( K f + K ) − h − v , the optimal airport charge is (16.2) w o p t | K f , K , X = X − c − N + 1 N b ( K f + K ) . That is, given the available airport capacity K f + K , when the observed travel demand pattern X is sufficiently large such that X ≥ c + b ( K f + K ) − h − v , the airport sets its service charge at X − c − N + 1 N b ( K f + K ) . The airport capacity will then be fully used. Any service charge that is not larger than this value will induce full capacity use and lead to maximum welfare. If the travel demand is not very large, the optimal airport charge will lead to partial capacity use. Now consider Stage 2, in which the airport decides how much of its reserve to use. The intuition for Proposition 4 is similar to that of a profit-maximizing airport. Detailed discussions are provided in the following section. 4 Comparison of results and discussion In the previous sections, the optimal prior capacity and reserve have been solved for both profit-maximizing and welfare-maximizing airports. As expected, the prior capacity and reserve choices are affected by many factors, including demand uncertainty, capacity and reserve costs, airline competition, the airport's objectives (which are usually determined by its ownership form), and possibly commercial services. We now compare the results from the cases considered to identify the effects of the various factors. 4.1 Comparison of a profit-maximizing and welfare-maximizing airport As reported in Propositions 2 and 4, the optimal prior capacity and reserve vary across the different regions defined by the combinations of values of r and r* (some graphs of sample solutions are provided in Appendix D). Optimal solutions may be obtained at the borders of these regions (i.e. corner solutions). As such, comparisons between profit-maximizing and welfare-maximizing airports can only be made conditionally, based on the regions of the values of r and r*. This also makes it difficult to draw general conclusions with respect to comparative statics. Table 1 reports the effects of various variables on the optimal choices of prior capacity and reserve. As the last two columns suggest, the effects of capital cost r and reserve cost r* are not always clear. A higher reserve cost leads to a larger prior capacity in certain cases (i.e. the first three cases reported in Proposition 2, or Eqs.. 11.1, 12.1, 13.1), but it has no effect when both the capital cost and reserve cost are high (i.e., when r ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ 2 and x ¯ − x ̲ 8 ≤ r * ≤ r 4 ). Still, there are some notable general conclusions, which are summarized as follows. • Compared with the welfare-maximizing airport benchmark, a profit-maximizing airport always chooses a smaller prior capacity and a smaller reserve. However, the under-investment issue can be alleviated by competition within the airline market. When the number of airlines increases, a profit-maximizing airport increases both its prior capacity and its reserve. • The optimal prior capacity of a welfare-maximizing airport always increases in h and v, whereas its reserve choice is always independent of h and v. The optimal capacity of a profit-maximizing airport increases in h but not in v, whereas its choice of reserve is not affected by h or v. Intuitively, a welfare-maximizing airport considers both concession profit and consumer surplus when making its prior capacity choices, whereas a profit-maximizing airport only considers profit. The new finding in this study is that the reserve is not affected by commercial services at all. An airport uses its reserve as a real option for expansion to avoid downsides and exploit upsides. Therefore, the size of the reserve chosen is only directly affected by demand variability, and the costs of the capacity and reserve. • In general, unless both the capacity cost r and reserve cost r* are high ( r ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ 2 and r * ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ 8 in our model), an airport always invests in a reserve. 6 6 It is assumed that r* ≤ r/4. If this assumption is relaxed, with a very high reserve cost the airport will not invest in an expansion option even if capital cost r is low. We are grateful to Robin Lindsey for pointing this out to us. When there is greater demand uncertainty (as measured by x ¯ − x ̲ ), a larger reserve will be invested in. In addition, when reserve is invested, a higher reserve cost r* leads to a larger prior capacity but a smaller reserve. A higher capital cost r leads to a smaller prior capacity. 4.2 Comparison with the case without real options To identify the effects of real options on airport capacity and performance, we now compare the outcomes of airport capacity investments with and without reserves. The decision process without a reserve or an expansion real option only involves three stages: In Stage 1, the airport decides its capacity. In Stage 2, conditional on the observed demand shifter X, the airport sets its airport charge to maximize its profit or total social welfare. In Stage 3, the airlines engage in Cournot competition to maximize their respective profits. Using derivations similar to those used in the previous sections, we can solve an airport's optimal capacity when real options for expansion are not available. Lemma 4 summarizes the results. Lemma 4 In the presence of future demand uncertainty, when real options for expansion are not available, the optimal capacities of a profit-maximizing airport and a welfare-maximizing airport are as follows. (a) If r < x ¯ − x ̲ 2 , a profit-maximizing airport and a welfare-maximizing airport will choose the following capacities respectively: (27.1) K ˜ p r o o p t = N 2 b ( N + 1 ) [ x ¯ − c + h − 2 r ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) ] , (27.2) K ˜ w e l o p t = 1 b [ x ¯ − c + h + v − 2 r ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) ] . (b) If r ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ 2 , a profit-maximizing airport and a welfare-maximizing airport will choose the following capacities respectively: (28.1) K ˜ p r o o p t = N 2 b ( N + 1 ) [ x ¯ − x ̲ 2 − c + h − r ] , (28.2) K ˜ w e l o p t = 1 b [ x ¯ − x ̲ 2 − c + h + v − r ] . The profit and welfare corresponding to the optimal capacities solved in Lemma 4 allow us to compare the outcomes with and without real options. For example, when r* is sufficiently small (in the sense that r * ≤ r 2 2 ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) ), the gain in expected social welfare using real options, denoted as IEW ≤, can be derived as (29.1) I E W ≤ = 1 6 b ( 3 r 2 + 3 d ( r − 2 r * ) − 4 2 d ( r 3 2 − 2 r * 3 2 ) ) When r* is relatively large (in the sense that r 2 2 ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) < r * ≤ r 4 ), the gain in expected social welfare from using a real option for expansion, which is denoted as IEW >, can be derived as (29.2) I E W > = 1 24 r b d ( 12 r 3 d + 12 r 2 d 2 + 12 r * 2 d 2 + 12 r * r 2 d − 24 r * r d 2 − r 4 − 16 2 r d 3 2 ( r 3 2 − r * 3 2 ) ) , where d = x ¯ − x ̲ . It can further be shown that ∂ ∂ d I E W ≤ > 0 , ∂ ∂ d I E W > > 0 , IEW ≤ > 0 and IEW > > 0. Similar results are obtained when we compare airport profits between cases with and without real options. We now summarize the main findings from the comparison between cases with and without real options as follows. • Unless both the capacity cost r and reserve cost r* are high ( r ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ 2 and r * ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ 8 in our model), an airport always invests in a reserve to maximize its expected profit or social welfare. Moreover, the sum of the prior capacity and reserve is larger than the optimal capacity when a real option for expansion is unavailable, that is, K f o p t < K ˜ and K f o p t + K r o p t > K ˜ for both profit-maximizing and welfare-maximizing airports. • Real options are beneficial to both profit-maximizing and welfare-maximizing airports. The welfare or profit gained from using real options increases with demand uncertainty. This probably explains why airports such as Seoul Incheon, Taipei Taoyuan, and the second airport in Sydney (at Badgerys creek) have carried out large-scale land-banking over extended periods. 4.3 Implications of alternative distribution of demand uncertainty In our analysis, the demand shifter X is assumed to follow a uniform distribution. Although such a specification has been used and discussed in previous investigations, including those by the Transportation Research Board (TRB, 2012), Xiao et al. (2013) and Xiao, Fu, Ng, and Zhang (2015a), few studies have examined the possible limitation of using a particular distribution. Most distributions used in the industry analyses reviewed by the Transportation Research Board (TRB, 2012) are symmetric. To examine the reliability of our modeling results, a binominal distribution specification of the demand shifter is tested for its asymmetry and mathematical tractability. Note that all analytical results obtained in stages 2–4 of the four-stage game continue to hold, because they are based on observed demand X. Therefore, we focus on the analysis of Stage 1. We consider the case when the demand shifter X follows a binomial distribution, where X takes the value of x ̲ with probability p and takes the value of x ¯ with probability 1-p. For a profit-maximizing airport, its objective function at Stage 1 is specified as (30) M a x K f , K r E Π = E [ ( w * + h ) Q * − r ( K f + K * ) − r * K r ] , where w*, Q*and K* are the optimal airport charge, derived demand and incremental capacity (i.e. utilized reserve) in Stage 2, respectively. As discussed earlier, it is assumed that x ≥ c + r – h; thus Kopt|X > 0 for both X = x ¯ and X = x ̲ . With a similar derivation process as reported in Section 3, the following Proposition 5 can be obtained. A sketched proof is provided in Appendix C. Proposition 5 For a profit-maximizing airport, its optimal prior capacity and reserve are as follows. 1) If r * ≤ min { p ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , r p } , the optimal prior capacity and reserve are (31.1) K f o p t = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ̲ − c + h − r + r * p ) (31.2) K r o p t = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r * p ( 1 − p ) ) 2) If p ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) ≤ r * < r and r > ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity and reserve are (32.1) K f o p t = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( ( 1 − p ) x ¯ + p x ̲ − c + h − r ) (32.2) K r o p t = 0 3) If rp ≤ r* < r and r ≤ ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity and reserve are (33.1) K f o p t = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ¯ − c + h − r 1 − p ) (33.2) K r o p t = 0 The objective function of a welfare-maximizing airport can be similarly specified as follows. (34) M a x K f , K r E SW = E [ − b 2 Q * 2 + ( X + h + v − c ) Q * − r ( K f + K * ) − r * K r ] As summarized in Appendix C, the following Proposition 6 can be obtained. Proposition 6 For a welfare-maximizing airport, its optimal prior capacity and reserve are as follows. 1) If r * ≤ min { p ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , r p } , the optimal prior capacity and reserve are (35.1) K f o p t = 1 b ( x ̲ − c + h + v − r + r * p ) (35.2) K r o p t = 1 b ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r * p ( 1 − p ) ) 2) If p ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) ≤ r * < r and r > ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity and reserve are (36.1) K f o p t = 1 b ( ( 1 − p ) x ¯ + p x ̲ − c + h + v − r ) (36.2) K r o p t = 0 3) If rp ≤ r* < r and r ≤ ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity and reserve are (37.1) K f o p t = 1 b ( x ¯ − c + h + v − r 1 − p ) (37.2) K r o p t = 0 With Propositions 2, 4, 5 and 6, it is clear that virtually all of the conclusions summarized in Section 4.1 remain valid in the case of binominal distribution. The only notable difference is that in the case of binominal distribution, if the reserve is very costly, then even if the capital cost is not very high (i.e., rp ≤ r* < r and r ≤ ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) in our model), no reserve will be acquired. With reference to Lemma 4, and Propositions 5 and 6, it is clear that the conclusions summarized in Section 4.2 continue to hold qualitatively. To summarize, whereas different specifications of the demand shifter do change the analytical solutions, the general conclusions appear to be fairly robust. Of course, such results are obtained when the rest of the model specifications remain unchanged. Further studies are needed to validate these conclusions in extended models. 4.4 Interpretation of the results and implications for the aviation industry Substantial demand uncertainty has been identified in the aviation industry. Maldonaldo (1990) found that 5-year forecasts of airport traffic could deviate from the actual volume by −36% to 96%, and 15-year forecasts could deviate by −34% to 210%. De Neufville and Barber (1991) analyze traffic volatility between 1968 and 1988 for the 38 largest U.S. airports and concluded that it clearly increased after the deregulation in 1978. De Neufville and Odoni (2003) study airport forecasting errors in the U.S., Japan, and Australia, and find significant biases even in aggregate forecasts at the national level. Although our study does not focus on calculating the monetary value of real options, 7 7 Some analytical solutions are defined as in Eqs. (29.1) and (29.2). A numerical example can be found in Smit (2003). such benefits are likely to be substantial. If Taipei and Sydney had not carried out land-banking, it is likely that alternative sites would have had to be obtained for new airports. This would not only have been costly, but may have been infeasible due to constraints such as air space, geographic conditions and community development. 8 8 Alternative sites for Sydney's second airport have been evaluated by various studies and organizations. It is generally agreed that the current site at Badgerys Creek, which has been reserved for decades, is the best choice overall when multiple factors are considered. With significant benefits at stake, it is puzzling that policy guidance and notable examples of real option applications have been so few. This may be ascribed to various issues, including the higher initial investment involved, limited government regulation and intervention, and complications with practical decisions due to additional dynamic factors. • Despite the higher airport profit and social welfare expected, the acquisition of real options involves a higher initial investment. As airport projects tend to be large and lumpy, short term financial constraints can override the long-term benefits brought by real options. Cooperation with airlines may be a solution to this. For example, airlines may serve as the guarantors of airport bonds to reduce interest costs (Fu et al., 2011). However, although most studies on airport-airline vertical arrangements find gains in airport profits and social welfare (Barbot, 2011; Barbot et al., 2013; D'Alfonso and Nastasi, 2012; Fu and Zhang, 2010; Yang et al. 2015; Zhang et al., 2010), a dominant airline may strategically influence airport capacity to achieve a competitive advantage over its rivals (Xiao et al. 2015b, and related discussions in Fu et al. 2015, Xiao et al. 2016). • Airport capacity is a core issue in long term planning, but it is not routinely reviewed by regulators. 9 9 Many airports monitor congestion and delays continuously. However, instead of designing for the right capacity, the purpose of this is generally to improve operation efficiency, or to allocate existing capacity (i.e. airport slots) more efficiently (Verhoef, 2010, Fukui, 2010, Li et al., 2010, Czerny, 2010, European Commission, 2011a, 2011b, Shen et al. 2015). Service quality at many airports in the U.K. and Australia is regularly monitored, and a few measures are linked to the availability of facilities (e.g. fixed electrical ground power serviceability, jetty serviceability, departure lounge seat availability and flight information). For further discussion see, for example, Civil Aviation Authority 2009, Yang and Fu 2015). However, these measures do not assess the core (runway) capacity which is the major constraint of airport throughput (De Neufville and Odoni, 2003). The optimal choice of reserve needs a good understanding of future demand (both the trend/mean and variability). Policy-makers often lack the expertise and information to regulate the choices of capacity and reserve, especially for private airports favoring under-investment. • Additional complicating factors are present in practical decision making. Our study suggests that airline competition tends to promote investment in both prior capacity and reserve. However, airline competition and airport capacity can be inter-active, and airport-airline vertical arrangements can have mixed implications for both airline competition and airport operations. Airport pricing and operations may affect low cost carriers and full service airlines differently (Fu et al. 2006; Oum and Fu, 2007). These two types of airlines tend to have different requirements for airport facilities and operations, and thus bring different revenue streams to airports (Barrett, 2004; Dresnereet al., 1996; Gillen and Lall, 2004; Windle and Dresner, 1999). All of these factors can complicate choices of airport capacity and reserves. For practical decisions related to regulatory policies and business strategies, additional factors may need to be considered in an extended model. Two notable areas for future research are investment timing and airport competition. In our model, a demand shifter is observed after prior capacity is invested. In practice, better information concerning demand can be obtained over time, even though the true growth pattern may never be perfectly identified. Therefore, considering investment timing and the information accumulated over time (see for example, Bernanke, 1983) is meaningful. Early investment leads to a timely supply of capacity in the case of high demand. However, a better forecast of demand growth patterns can be obtained through more observations of actual traffic volume. For such a trade-off, optimal investment timing is called for. In certain cases, there is a need to consider investment timing and competition simultaneously, an approach referred to as the “option game” (Azevedo and Paxson, 2014; Baldursson, 1998; Chevalier et al. 2011; Ferreira et al. 2009; Smit and Ankum, 1993; Smit and Trigeorgis, 2004). In our model, airline competition influences traffic volume and thus the airport's choices regarding capacity and reserve. Such a vertical relationship between the airport and its airlines is however different from horizontal airport rivalry. Accordingly, it is important to consider airport competition and the use of real options in an integrated option game model. Many metropolitan areas already have or are planning secondary airports. Airports in the same region may be owned or managed by the same authority (e.g. New York, Tokyo, Shanghai) or competing/separate decision-makers (e.g. London, Washington-Baltimore area, San Francisco area, the Pearl River delta area which includes five airports in mainland China, Macau and Hong Kong). Extending our model to include multi-airport systems would thus be of great theoretical and practical importance. Although our model incorporates some distinctive features of the airport industry, due to the possible complications discussed above, caution should be exercised when generalized recommendations are made based on one analytical study. What regulators can do immediately is to encourage airports to explore the opportunities for using real options, and facilitate such applications. Indeed, without government intervention, it would have been impossible for cities such as Seoul, Taipei and Sydney to reserve the land they needed for future airport expansion. As Slade (2001) points out, “routine application of real-option theory to practical investment problems is not likely to become the norm in the near future. Nevertheless, the qualitative insights that the theory offers are undoubtedly valuable.” 5 Summary and conclusions In this paper we develop a multi-stage game model that identifies the optimal capacity to be immediately invested (i.e. prior capacity) and the size of the land or other resources to be reserved for possible future expansion (the reserve). The model analyzes airports’ capacity investment, which has large sunk-costs and significant demand uncertainty, accounting for an airport's pricing decisions, airline competition and alternative airport objectives (profit maximization vs. welfare maximization). The analytical results from the model offer fresh insight into capacity investment at airports and have important policy implications. In general, our findings indicate that using real options in capacity planning can be a valuable tool for airports to battle uncertainty, especially for capacity investment when demand uncertainty is high. Our findings also suggest that market competition is essential to the success of airport privatization in that competition in the airline market promotes capacity investment and the adoption of real options by profit-maximizing airports. Although we try to explicitly model the fundamental factors in airport capacity choices with real options, additional issues may need to be examined in extended models. For example, the effects of airport-airline vertical arrangements and the influence of dominant airlines could be substantial in oligopolistic aviation markets. Other issues such as investment timing, airport competition and possible government regulation could have significant implications for the optimal choices of airport capacity and reserve. A few simplifying assumptions are also imposed in our analysis to ensure mathematical tractability. For example, the assumption that travel demand is linear might be restrictive. It would be good to test general functional forms in the future so that the robustness of our conclusions can be validated. Further, in our analysis the cost of reserve r* is modeled as an exogenous parameter. In practice, it is possible that such a cost is negotiated with the supplier of the real option (e.g. the landlord in the case of land banking), or is dependent on the amount of the reserve to be acquired (e.g. quantity discount for a larger reserve). Explicitly considering these factors may offer fresh insight into the overall economic effects of real options, and a “global” optimal outcome may be identified for airports and their suppliers. These extensions and improvements will contribute to the burgeoning literature on real option applications in transportation. We hope that our model can lead to more advanced studies on this important topic in analyses of the aviation industry. Appendix C Sketched solutions when the demand shifter follows a binomial distribution This appendix provides sketched solutions for an airport's optimal choices for prior capacity and reserve when the demand shifter X follows a binomial distribution as defined in Section 4.3. Due to space limitations, only the key results are summarized. We will first analyze the case of a profit-maximizing airport, then provide a brief introduction for the case of a welfare-maximizing airport. A profit-maximizing airport For the profit maximization problem as specified in Eq. (30), it is assumed that x ≥ c + r − h, and thus, that Kopt|X > 0 for both X = x ¯ and X = x ̲ . Clearly, the airport's prior capacity Kf is in the range of [ K o p t | x ̲ , K o p t | x ¯ ] whereas reserveKr is in the range of [ 0 , K o p t | x ¯ − K f ] . For ease of notion and derivation, we define some variables as follows: (C1) X 1 = c − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b K f , X 2 = c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b K f , X 3 = c + r − h + 2 ( N + 1 ) N b ( K f + K r ) , K B 1 = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ̲ − c − r + h ) K B 2 = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ¯ − c − r + h ) , K B 3 = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ̲ − c + h ) It can be verified that KB1 < KB2 ≤ KB3 if r ≥ x ¯ − x ̲ , otherwise KB1 < KB3 < KB2 if r < x ¯ − x ̲ . With reference to ΠIa, ΠIb, ΠII , and ΠIII as defined in Eqs. (6)-(8), respectively, the airport's expected profit can be specified for the following cases. Case I: r < x ¯ − x ̲ In this case, KB1 < KB3 < KB2. It can be derived that when KB1 ≤ Kf ≤ KB3 and Kf + Kr ≤ KB2, the conditions X 1 ≤ x ̲ ≤ X 2 and x ¯ ≥ X 3 both hold, and thus the airport's expected profit is E Π 1 = p Π I b | X = x ̲ + ( 1 − p ) Π I I I | X = x ¯ . When KB3 ≤ Kf ≤ KB2 and Kf + Kr ≤ KB2, the conditions x ̲ ≤ X 1 and x ¯ ≥ X 3 both hold, and thus the airport's expected profit is E Π 2 = p Π I a | X = x ̲ + ( 1 − p ) Π I I I | X = x ¯ . The airport's profit function and constraint conditions are all convex, and the following conclusions can be obtained. Conclusion C1.1 When KB 1 ≤ Kf ≤ KB 3. • If r * ≥ ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r ) and r < ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity is K f = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ̲ − c + h ) and the optimal reserve is K r = 0 . • If r * ≥ p ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) and r > ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity is K f = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( ( 1 − p ) x ¯ + p x ̲ − c + h − r ) and the optimal reserve is K r = 0 . • If r* ≥ rp and r * ≤ ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r ) , the optimal prior capacity is K f = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ̲ − c + h ) and the optimal reserve is K r = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r − r * 1 − p ) . • If r* ≤ rp and r * ≤ p ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity is K f = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ̲ − c + h − r + r * p ) and the optimal reserve is K r = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r * p ( 1 − p ) ) . Conclusion C1.2 When KB 3 ≤ Kf ≤ KB 2 . • If r * ≥ ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r ) and r < ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity is K f = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ̲ − c + h ) and the optimal reserve is K r = 0 . • If r* ≥ rp and r ≤ ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ ) , the optimal prior capacity is K f = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ¯ − c + h − r 1 − p ) , and the optimal reserve is K r = 0 . • If r * ≤ ( 1 − p ) ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r ) and r* ≤ rp, the optimal prior capacity is K f = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ̲ − c + h ) and the optimal reserve is K r = N 2 ( N + 1 ) b ( x ¯ − x ̲ − r − r * 1 − p ) . Appendix D Graphic presentation of the optimal prior capacity and reserve There are many sub-cases involved with deriving the optimal solutions for prior capacity K f o p t and reserve K r o p t . In the case of a profit-maximizing airport, the optimal solutions within certain parameters are presented in the following figures. For simplicity, we consider cases in which the airline market is perfectly competitive (i.e., when N tends to infinity), with the other key parameters chosen from the ranges defined in our analytical solutions (e.g. to ensure positive traffic volume). As shown across the figures, the optimal solutions follow different patterns within the regions defined by different values of r and r*, which are also affected by demand variability (i.e. ranges of x ̲ , x ¯ ). Similar patterns can be observed for a welfare-maximizing airport. Therefore, it is not always possible to benchmark the solutions across the scenarios analyzed. As shown in the figures, the horizontal axes correspond to parameter values of r and r*, respectively. The vertical axes report the values of prior capacity K f o p t and reserve K r o p t , respectively. In each figure, the four surfaces in green, red, blue and yellow correspond to the four cases of optimal prior capacity or reserve as defined in Proposition 2 (i.e. Eqs. (11)-(14), respectively). coredata.dc:description: Abstract This study models airport capacity choice when a real option for expansion can be purchased. Facing demand uncertainty, an airport first determines the capacity for immediate investment (the prior capacity) and the size of the land or other resources to be reserved for possible future expansion (the reserve). Once demand is observed, the airport can use a portion of the reserve to build extra capacity and set airport charge. Our analytical results show that if demand uncertainty is low and capacity and reserve costs are relatively high, an airport will not acquire a real option for expansion. Otherwise, it can use an expansion option to improve its expected profit or social welfare. Both the magnitude of profit or welfare gain and the optimal size of the reserve increase with demand uncertainty. A higher reserve cost leads to a larger prior capacity and a smaller reserve, whereas a higher capital cost leads to lower prior capacity. A profit-maximizing airport would choose a smaller prior capacity and reserve than would a welfare-maximizing airport. Competition within the airline market promotes airport capacity investment and the adoption of real options by profit-maximizing airports, whereas airport commercial services increase prior capacity but not the reserve.
coredata.dc:title: Modeling airport capacity choice with real options
